question_text: For the same patient [referring to Q273, hemorrhage with fluid level], what is the recommended treatment?

options.A: Osmotic therapy

options.A: MRI

question_text: In a scenario of superior cerebellar artery (SCA) infarction, what additional finding would you expect?

options.A: Right ptosis ipsilateral to the ataxia
options.B: Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome associated with ataxia

question_text: An elderly patient presents with 6 hours of right-sided weakness affecting the arm, leg, and face, along with mild dysarthria. A brain CT shows an acute left internal capsule infarction. What is the earliest finding of brain cell ischemia?

options.A: Astrocyte fragmentation

question_text: An AIS patient within the window with a platelet count of 45,000 was given tPA which resulted in intracranial hemorrhage. What violation to the AIS treatment protocol was done?

options.A: Out of the tPA window

question_text: An 83-year-old man presents with a 3-hour history of stroke. What is the next best step in management?

options.A: CTA

question_text: Which of the following is a common neurologic deficit associated with AICA (Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery) infarction?

options.A: Headache

question_text: In a patient post motor vehicle accident (MVA) presenting with symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, what is the likely mechanism of stroke?

options.A: Vertebral artery thrombosis

options.A: It is effective and recommended
options.D: It is only effective in combination with other medications

question_text: In a case of subacute stroke with a CT brain showing no abnormalities, a normal transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE), and a normal 48-hour Holter monitor, what is the next best step in management?

options.A: Prolonged cardiac monitoring

question_text: What are the effects caused by SCA? [Referring to Superior Cerebellar Artery infarction]

options.A: Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome/ptosis
